awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the emergent collective biophysical behavior of platelets in blood clotting
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Blood clotting is a natural process that prevents blood loss from damaged vessels and restores normal blood circulation in the body. Upon injury, a chain of events culminates in the formation of a plug of cells and polymeric biomaterial that attaches to the wound edges. Platelets, the small disk-shaped cells in circulation, become activated and apply contractile forces to shrink the overall size of the clot and mechanically stabilize the repair to allow it to withstand forces applied by flowing blood and physical movements. Unhealthy changes to the blood clotting process are a leading cause of death and disability worldwide and are associated with a range of severe medical conditions such as hemophilia, stroke, and heart attack. This project seeks to investigate the complex dynamic behavior of platelets within blood clots using state of the art experimental and computational methods. As platelet biophysical properties, such as size, force, and activity can vary widely among species, the properties of platelets from humans, mice, dogs, cows, and chickens will be compared to pinpoint their influence on blood clotting. The results of this project will facilitate the development of new treatments and medical diagnostics to mitigate adverse effects of unhealthy clotting. In addition, the project will train graduate and undergraduate students in solving cross-disciplinary engineering and biomedical problems. The project will advance HealthReach, an education program aiming to engage in STEM learning K-12 students with chronic illnesses, who are often educationally disadvantaged due to frequent treatments, school absences, and other medially related issues. 

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This project seeks to investigate the fundamental biophysical behaviors and interactions of platelets within a blood clot that is an actively contracting material. During blood clot formation, contracting platelets pull on a nascent polymeric fibrin mesh, yet the mechanics and dynamics of this active process remain poorly understood, despite links to bleeding and clotting disorders. This is in part due to our limited understanding of platelet properties and function, especially their emerging cooperativity as they collectively apply forces to the clot fibrin network. This interdisciplinary project will integrate experiments and computational modeling to investigate clot contraction in different species including human, mouse, dog, cow, and chicken platelets that exhibit diverse physiological properties. The experiments will characterize platelet activity and interactions within the fibrin network. This information will be used to develop a mesoscale model of clot contraction that will take into account micromechanics and dynamics of platelets and will provide insight into the clot structural changes due to platelet activity and contraction. The project will focus on understanding the role of platelet heterogeneity, cooperation, activation patterns, and clot contraction mechanics to reveal the connection between the behavior of a single platelet, the collective platelet behavior, and the properties of bulk clots. By providing fundamental insights into the effects of platelet heterogeneity on the clot dynamics, the project will develop new strategies for designing novel bio-inspired active materials. Furthermore, the project will provide important insights into animal models used for bleeding and clotting research

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Blood clotting is the final step in hemostasis, resulting in the sealing of an injured blood vessel and preventing excessive bleeding. Blood clotting is a highly complex multi-stage and multi-scale process involving platelet activation, polymerization of fibrin networks, development of a platelet-fibrin plug that undergoes platelet-driven contraction process to restore normal blood flow. Understanding of the physics underlying the clotting process is critical for effective diagnosis and treatment of a variety of blood clotting disorders associated with life threatening conditions including excessive bleeding, stroke, and heart attack. Furthermore, cell-driven matrix contraction finds diverse applications in novel active polymer materials. This project investigated the complex dynamic behavior of platelets within blood clots, utilizing experiments at both single cell and bulk clot level, and mesoscale modeling of blood clot contraction that links microscale and macroscale phenomena.

The project revealed new information on how blood clot contraction proceeds and what forces clot can generate. The results showed that the collective microscopic movements of platelets interacting with fibrin scaffolds mediate significant macroscopic changes, resulting in dramatic decrease in clot size and increase in clot stiffness. The research disclosed that platelets utilize the inherent heterogeneity associated with their action to enhance volumetric clot contraction and to magnify contractile forces. Thus, cell heterogeneity can carry an essential biophysical function in cell-matrix biomaterials. Furthermore, heterogeneity can be harnessed to increase mechanical efficiency in diverse systems including implantable biomaterials, robot swarms, and active polymer composites. The work explained the mechanism by which individual platelets induce forces in bulk clots and provided a relationship between the single platelet force and the clot force, applicable to a variety of physiologically relevant clots. The work provided new insights into the interactions among contracting fibrin-platelet clots, red blood cells (RBCs), and flow. The results revealed the conditions at which RBCs are entrapped in contracted clots. The trapped RBCs act as physical constrains to restrict the contraction of the fibrin network, leading to weaker clot volume reduction. The results are important for better understanding of the blood clots formation and behavior at different locations within human body. 

In terms of education outreach, the project supported the training, professional, and leadership development of one female PhD student. The student trained in advanced computational modeling with application to the interdisciplinary research problems such as blood clotting and polymer physics and served as the president of the Mechanical Engineering Graduate Association (MEGA) at Georgia Tech. The project engaged an undergraduate student in active research. The undergraduate student received the President's Undergraduate Research Award (PURA) at Georgia Tech for working on this project. The project supported HealthReach, is an undergraduate class in the biomedical engineering (BME) department at Georgia Tech taught by Dr. Lam and his lab, in which Georgia Tech undergraduates create and design hands-on interactive STEM activities for the Children's Healthcare of Atlanta (CHOA) patients using the kids? own diseases as springboards for learning. Throughout the grant, Georgia Tech undergraduates design and teach STEM activities to pediatric patients. Specifically, 93 Georgia Tech undergraduates have had over 2100 sickle cell disease patient encounters at CHOA hospitals.
